articles.headline: Biden Administration Is Likely to Delay Decision Over U.S. Steel
articles.snippet: The White House has faced backlash for politicizing its review of Nippon Steel’s takeover of the company.
articles.abstract: The White House has faced backlash for politicizing its review of Nippon Steel’s takeover of the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is likely to delay a final decision on whether to block the sale of U.S. Steel to Nippon Steel of Japan until after the election, slowing a process that has been caught up in presidential politics, according to people familiar with the matter.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Andrew Duehren and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Paraguay Loves Mickey, Its Cartoon Mouse. Disney Doesn’t.
articles.snippet: Mickey, a homegrown food-packaging company, is famous for facing down Disney in Paraguay’s Supreme Court. As the family business turns 90, why is it still so popular?
articles.abstract: Mickey, a homegrown food-packaging company, is famous for facing down Disney in Paraguay’s Supreme Court. As the family business turns 90, why is it still so popular?
articles.lead_paragraph: One is a colossus spanning theme parks, merchandise and movies, with 150 Academy Awards, 225,000 employees and annual revenue of nearly $90 billion.
articles.byline: By Laurence Blair and María Magdalena Arréllaga

articles.headline: 20 Million Cards: A Sports Memorabilia Gold Mine Uncovered in Virginia
articles.snippet: Three years ago, a businessman bought a collection of roughly 20 million sports cards from its reclusive owner. Now he wants to show it to the world.
articles.abstract: Three years ago, a businessman bought a collection of roughly 20 million sports cards from its reclusive owner. Now he wants to show it to the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a former antique shop off a four-lane highway in rural Virginia, Tim Banazek knelt before a white banker’s box labeled “Autographed Baseballs” that was stashed at the bottom of a steel bookcase. He pulled the first ball out and examined the signature in the fluorescent light. It was Willie Mays’s.

articles.headline: Nixon Started the War on Drugs. Privately, He Said Pot Was ‘Not Particularly Dangerous.’
articles.snippet: President Richard Nixon’s remarks were captured on his secret White House recording system but had eluded the notice of leading Nixon era historians until now.
articles.abstract: President Richard Nixon’s remarks were captured on his secret White House recording system but had eluded the notice of leading Nixon era historians until now.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years after former President Richard M. Nixon launched a war on drugs in 1971, calling substance use the nation’s “public enemy No. 1,” he made a startling admission during a meeting in the Oval Office.

articles.headline: Once Considered Foes, Iranian-Backed Groups Get a Warm Welcome From Iraq
articles.snippet: Hamas and the Houthis have opened offices in Baghdad, reflecting the two groups’ evolving relationship with Iraq as Tehran works to build a regional power bloc.
articles.abstract: Hamas and the Houthis have opened offices in Baghdad, reflecting the two groups’ evolving relationship with Iraq as Tehran works to build a regional power bloc.
articles.lead_paragraph: There is no sign on the door of the new Hamas political office in Baghdad, and the address is closely guarded. The same goes for the new Houthi office, a short drive away.

articles.headline: How Roberts Shaped Trump’s Supreme Court Winning Streak
articles.snippet: Behind the scenes, the chief justice molded three momentous Jan. 6 and election cases that helped determine the former president’s fate.
articles.abstract: Behind the scenes, the chief justice molded three momentous Jan. 6 and election cases that helped determine the former president’s fate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last February, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. sent his eight Supreme Court colleagues a confidential memo that radiated frustration and certainty.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Adam Liptak

articles.headline: ‘The Yellowstone Effect’: Cities Cash In on Cowboy Culture
articles.snippet: Lands in cities and towns that were once shipping points for livestock can be low-lying, unfavorable and often prone to flooding. They’re also hotbeds for new developments.
articles.abstract: Lands in cities and towns that were once shipping points for livestock can be low-lying, unfavorable and often prone to flooding. They’re also hotbeds for new developments.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seems everyone is a little country these days: Markets for western-themed fashion have been re-energized and country music is hotter than it’s been in decades.

articles.headline: How a Tourist Paradise Became a Drug-Trafficking Magnet
articles.snippet: Costa Rica’s lush rainforests, which blanket a quarter of the country, are being infiltrated by cartels on a quest to find new trafficking routes to evade the authorities.
articles.abstract: Costa Rica’s lush rainforests, which blanket a quarter of the country, are being infiltrated by cartels on a quest to find new trafficking routes to evade the authorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before Christian Puchi set off for work in the rainforest, he made sure his machete was fastened to his hip and his fellow forest rangers were doused in mosquito repellent. They jumped in their boat and navigated through throngs of tourists already on the water.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Alejandro Cegarra

articles.headline: Despite Relentless Russian Attack, Life in Kharkiv Endures Underground
articles.snippet: Kharkiv, Ukraine, has adjusted to life amid the threat of bombings. Its resilience is manifested in a curious blend of life above and below ground.
articles.abstract: Kharkiv, Ukraine, has adjusted to life amid the threat of bombings. Its resilience is manifested in a curious blend of life above and below ground.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the war-ravaged city of Kharkiv, where the echoes of air-raid alerts are commonplace, an unlikely sound filled a dimly lit underground garage on a recent morning: the soaring voices of soprano and baritone singers.
articles.byline: By Daniel Berehulak, Constant Méheut and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

articles.headline: White-Collar Workers Are Getting Squeezed. Even Oscar-Winning Producers.
articles.snippet: Corporate consolidation and technology have upended many jobs in recent decades. But few arcs are more surprising than that of the Hollywood producer.
articles.abstract: Corporate consolidation and technology have upended many jobs in recent decades. But few arcs are more surprising than that of the Hollywood producer.
articles.lead_paragraph: In more than three decades as a studio executive and producer, Kevin Misher has worked on some of the most beloved movies in Hollywood, including “Rudy,” “Meet the Parents” and “Public Enemies.”

articles.headline: ‘Beetlejuice Beetlejuice’ Hands Warner Bros. a Lifeline
articles.snippet: The movie has made roughly $190 million in its first 10 days, giving the studio a needed hit after a summer of misfires.
articles.abstract: The movie has made roughly $190 million in its first 10 days, giving the studio a needed hit after a summer of misfires.
articles.lead_paragraph: Warner Bros. managed only a 4.7 percent share of domestic movie-ticket sales over the summer. By that measure, it was Warner’s worst performance since analysts started to compile seasonal box office data in 1982.

articles.headline: 3 Georgia Women, Caught Up in a Flood of Suspicion About Voting
articles.snippet: An election skeptic challenged hundreds of voter registrations, including one for a voting rights activist. A county official is dealing with the mess.
articles.abstract: An election skeptic challenged hundreds of voter registrations, including one for a voting rights activist. A county official is dealing with the mess.
articles.lead_paragraph: Helen Strahl stood at the front of a conference room in Savannah, Ga., last month and looked out at her audience, the evolving face of election denialism in 2024. There were no armed militia groups in attendance, no would-be revolutionaries dressed in capes and horns. The crowd was mostly made up of retirees and professional women, including some who wore glasses and T-shirts that read: “Got data?”
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Hilary Swift

articles.headline: Trump Safe After What F.B.I. Describes as an Assassination Attempt
articles.snippet: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was investigating what appeared to be a second assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said it was investigating what appeared to be a second assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live coverage of the apparent assassination attempt on Donald Trump.
articles.byline: By Patricia Mazzei, Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Adam Goldman and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: In New York Case, Signs of a Familiar China Playbook
articles.snippet: Linda Sun is just the latest member of the Chinese diaspora whom Beijing is accused of recruiting to influence Western democracies.
articles.abstract: Linda Sun is just the latest member of the Chinese diaspora whom Beijing is accused of recruiting to influence Western democracies.
articles.lead_paragraph: A prominent lawyer in Britain, accused of trying to advance Beijing’s interests in Parliament.

articles.headline: Will TikTok Be Banned in January? That Question Is Headed to Court.
articles.snippet: TikTok will be in federal court on Monday, aiming to block a new law that will ban the popular video app in the United States early next year.
articles.abstract: TikTok will be in federal court on Monday, aiming to block a new law that will ban the popular video app in the United States early next year.
articles.lead_paragraph: TikTok could be banned in the United States in mere months. Its lawyers head to court on Monday to fight that outcome, the latest stage in an ongoing clash between the short-form video app and the American government.

articles.headline: Big Energy Issue in Pennsylvania Is Low Natural Gas Prices. Not Fracking.
articles.snippet: Energy businesses and farmers in western Pennsylvania are struggling because of prices, an issue that has not figured prominently in the campaigns of Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris.
articles.abstract: Energy businesses and farmers in western Pennsylvania are struggling because of prices, an issue that has not figured prominently in the campaigns of Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of the American shale boom of the last two decades, natural gas producers found that the more they pumped, the more demand grew, as cheaper gas displaced coal.

articles.headline: The Fed Is Still Banking on a Labor Market Miracle
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve is poised to lower interest rates this week. Recent jobs data have been a reminder that a soft landing is not yet assured.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve is poised to lower interest rates this week. Recent jobs data have been a reminder that a soft landing is not yet assured.
articles.lead_paragraph: An object in motion stays in motion. Is a labor market trend that’s well underway any different?

articles.headline: FX Outduels Bigger Rivals to Collect Huge Emmy Haul
articles.snippet: The network has been a darling among critics for years. But it hit a new high on Sunday, with “Shogun” winning best drama and “The Bear” picking up several awards as well.
articles.abstract: The network has been a darling among critics for years. But it hit a new high on Sunday, with “Shogun” winning best drama and “The Bear” picking up several awards as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the “Shogun” writer and producer Justin Marks stormed the Emmys stage after his show won best drama on Sunday night, his first order of business was to pay tribute to the people who helped bring him there: the executive team at FX.
